questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not show this type of giant cells?
questions.solution:
Langhans' giant cells have horseshoe-shaped nuclei arrangement at one pole of the cell. These are formed by fusion of epithelioid cells. They are not phagocytic but secrete interleukins and help in inflammation. These giant cells are seen in granulomatous conditions like-

  • Tubercular granuloma
  • Tuberculoid leprosy
  • Deep fungal infection
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leishmaniasis
  • Crohn's disease

In lepromatous leprosy there is diffuse infiltration of macrophages, plasma cells. There is a clear Grenz zone. Many foam cells with globi-cigar shaped bundles of M. leprae inside macrophage. These swollen macrophages packed with bacilli are known as lepra or Virchow cells.

Reference: IAL textbook of Leprosy, 2nd edition, page 487

questions.text: A 40 year old patient presented with complaints of fluid filled lesion over skin which ruptured on its own leading to crust formation. Direct immunoflourescence image is given. What will be the diagnosis?

  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita - Continuous homogeneous deposition of C3 along the BMZ
  • Linear IgA disease - Linear IgA along the BMZ
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis - Granular deposition of IgA along the BMZ and dermal papillae

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with a 10-day history of tearing, redness, and decreased vision of his right eye. He denies trauma. Slit-lamp examination reveals the findings in the figure. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This man has a vascular necrosis of his conjunctiva, episclera, and sclera, with signs of acute inflammation. These signs are characteristic of necrotizing scleritis with inflammation, which accounts for approximately 10% of all cases of anterior scleritis.

Another 10% of patients with anterior scleritis have necrotizing scleritis without inflammation, also known as scleromalacia perforans (Option C). Most patients with scleromalacia perforans have long-standing rheumatoid arthritis, little sign of inflammation, and areas of thin, often staphylomatous sclera through which dark choroid can be seen.

Option B - About 40% of patients with anterior scleritis have nodular scleritis, characterized by an inflamed, immobile, nodular thickening of the sclera. The remaining 40% of patients with anterior scleritis have diffuse scleritis. Diffuse scleritis is the most benign form and is often not associated with an underlying systemic condition.

Option D - A Pseudomonas scleral ulcer would more likely be seen in the context of contact lens wear or trauma.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology 9th edition pg. 295

questions.text: This infant developed intermittent diarrhea and a rash over his fingers, face and perianal area. What is the best treatment for the child?
questions.solution:
The child is suffering from acrodermatitis enteropathica. This is an autosomal recessive condition with a defect in zinc absorption.

The clinical features appear in the first few weeks of life if the child is on bottle milk or when it is weaned off. Erythematous and crusted, sometimes vesicular and pustular, lesions appear in areas around the nose, mouth, eyes and perianal area, and a psoriasiform rash may occur on the knees and elbows. Secondary bacterial and fungal infection is common.

Low serum zinc is found and treatment consists of giving oral zinc (this is a lifelong requirement).

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 3238

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient with a past history of ischemic heart disease presented to hospital with acute onset breathlessness & features of the patient are shown in images given below. A diagnosis of congestive heart failure was made. Which of the following is the immediate best drug for the treatment of congestion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Almost all cases of symptomatic heart failure are treated with a diuretic. High ceiling diuretics (furosemide, bumetanide) are the diuretics of choice for mobilizing edema fluid; later they may be continued in low doses. However, resistance may develop to even high ceiling diuretics after prolonged use in advanced heart failure.

Addition of metolazone or spironolactone to furosemide may overcome the resistance.

Thiazide alone has a very limited role in CHF. Diuretics: Remove peripheral edema and pulmonary congestion.

Intravenous furosemide promptly increases systemic venous capacitance and produces rapid symptomatic relief in acute left ventricular failure. Decrease preload and improve ventricular efficiency by reducing circulating volume.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th /e p563

questions.text: A 46 year old female patient undergoes lumbar puncture for the diagnosis of viral meningitis. CSF report comes normal. After 10 days the patient had a headache which occurs on sitting or standing upright and is relieved after lying down. A low CSF headache is suspected. Her MRI brain is shown below. What is a false statement regarding this?
questions.solution:
MRI showing diffuse meningeal enhancement after gadolinium administration in a patient with low cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume headache.

  • Low CSF Volume Headache

In these syndromes, head pain is positional: it begins when the patient sits or stands upright and resolves upon reclining. The pain, which is occipitofrontal, is usually a dull ache but may be throbbing.

Patients with chronic low CSF volume headache typically present with a history of headache from one day to the next that is generally not present on waking but worsens during the day. Recumbency usually improves the headache within minutes, and it can take only minutes to an hour for the pain to return when the patient resumes an upright position.

The most common cause of headache due to persistent low CSF volume is CSF leak following LP. Post-LP headache usually begins within 48 h but may be delayed for up to 12 days. Its incidence is between 10% and 30%. Beverages with caffeine may provide temporary relief. Besides LP, index events may include epidural injection or a vigorous Valsalva maneuver, such as from lifting, straining, coughing, clearing the eustachian tubes in an airplane, or multiple orgasms.

When imaging is indicated to identify the source of a presumed leak, an MRI with gadolinium is the initial study of choice. A striking pattern of diffuse meningeal enhancement is so typical that in the appropriate clinical context the diagnosis is established.

Initial treatment for low CSF volume headache is bed rest.

For patients with persistent pain, IV caffeine (500 mg in 500 mL of saline administered over 2 h) can be very effective. An electrocardiogram (ECG) to screen for arrhythmia should be performed before administration. It is reasonable to administer at least two infusions of caffeine before embarking on additional tests to identify the source of the CSF leak.

If a leak can be identified, an autologous blood patch is usually curative. A blood patch is also effective for post-LP headache; in this setting, the location is empirically determined to be the site of the LP.

In patients with intractable headache, oral theophylline is a useful alternative that can take some months to be effective.

Option A - Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) can present with orthostatic headache similar to low CSF volume headache and is a diagnosis that needs consideration in this setting.

Option D - Chiari malformations may sometimes be noted on MRI; in such cases, surgery to decompress the posterior fossa is not indicated and usually worsens the headache.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 116

questions.text: What is the minimum volume of free air under the diaphragm that can be detected by an erect CXR?
questions.solution:
• The erect chest x-ray (CXR) is the ideal first test for hollow organ perforation and as little as 10-20 mL of free air can be detected under the diaphragm.
  • About 10 minutes should be left between sitting the patient upright and taking the film to allow time for air to rise
  • The free air must be sought under the right hemidiaphragm to prevent misinterpretation of the gastric air bubble
  • The reviewer must be able to recognise Chilaiditi's syndrome, the harmless and asymptomatic interposition of the large bowel between the liver and diaphragm.
  • Caution must also be exercised in interpreting any free air in the context of recent abdominal surgery, as postoperative air can persist for up to 5-7 days in the peritoneal cavity.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 137

questions.text: All are false about the following diathermy current except -
questions.solution:
Diathermy current can be used in coagulation mode to control bleeding by clotting blood vessels.

Diathermy current typically involves higher voltage, which allows it to generate the necessary heat for cutting or coagulation.

In diathermy, the current is typically on continuously during the application.

Diathermy can have a significant lateral spread of heat, which can affect nearby tissues. Surgeons need to be cautious when using diathermy to avoid unintended tissue damage.

questions.text: A 18 year old male patient had nystagmus, partial oculocutaneous albinism, and an increased number of infections resulting from many bacterial agents. His peripheral smear is shown below. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
Peripheral smear shows -

Granulocytes contain huge cytoplasmic granules formed from aggregation and fusion of azurophilic and specific granules. Large abnormal granules are found in other granule-containing cells throughout the body

Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (CHS) is a rare disease with autosomal recessive inheritance due to defects in the lysosomal transport protein LYST, encoded by the gene CHS1 at 1q42.

This protein is required for normal packaging and disbursement of granules. Neutrophils (and all cells containing lysosomes) from patients with CHS characteristically have large granules , making it a systemic disease.

Patients with CHS have nystagmus, partial oculocutaneous albinism, and an increased number of infections resulting from many bacterial agents.

Some CHS patients develop an 'accelerated phase' in childhood with a hemophagocytic syndrome and an aggressive lymphoma requiring marrow transplantation.

CHS neutrophils and monocytes have impaired chemotaxis and abnormal rates of microbial killing due to slow rates of fusion of the lysosomal granules with phagosomes.

NK cell function is also impaired. CHS patients may develop a severe disabling peripheral neuropathy in adulthood.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 446, 447

questions.text: A 12 year old male patient had fever since 3 days. Patient develops a rash over the truncal region shown in the images. Rashes are not seen in palms and soles. Patient had a spot in the buccal mucosa also. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Centrally distributed rashes, in which lesions are primarily truncal, are the most common type of eruption.

The rash of rubeola (measles) starts the hairline 2-3 days into the illness and moves down the body, typically sparing the palms and soles. It begins as discrete erythematous lesions, which become confluent as the rash spreads.

Koplik's spots (1- to 2-mm white or bluish lesions with an erythematous halo on the buccal mucosa) are pathognomonic for measles and are generally seen during the first 2 days of symptoms.

They should not be confused with Fordyce's spots (ectopic sebaceous glands), which have no erythematous halos and are found in the mouth of healthy individuals.

Koplik's spots may briefly overlap with the measles exanthem.

Option B - In rubella rashes Spreads from hairline downward, clearing as it spreads and Forchheimer spots are seen.

Option C - In chikungunya fever Maculopapular eruption; typically occurs on trunk, but also occurs on extremities and face.

Option D - Herpes is characterized by Erythema rapidly followed by hallmark painful grouped vesicles that may evolve into pustules that ulcerate, especially on mucosal surfaces; lesions at site of inoculation: commonly gingivostomatitis for HSV-1 and genital lesions for HSV-2; recurrent disease milder (e.g., herpes labialis does not involve oral mucosa).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 136-13

questions.text: A patient developed cellulitis, isolated organism is showing, result. The causative organism is
questions.solution:
The given test is showing positive slide coagulase test - a feature of Staphylococcus aureus.

Staphylococcus causes a range of infections. Cellulitis ,boil, blisters and redness of the skin. These infections can be anywhere on your body, including your face often around your mouth and nose.

It can also cause food poisoning, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, pneumonia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis.

Staphylococcus are easily grown on blood agar, nutrient agar.

To confirm, a coagulase test is to be done. It can be done by -

  • Slide method
  • Tube method

In the slide test, suspension of s aureus is taken and plasma is added. If a small coagulum is formed, it is positive. If not it is negative.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition - Page no 200

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the given image.
questions.solution:
The image shows the bullous lesion in the lung parenchyma in upper zone.

Emphysema is classified into distinct pathologic types, which include centrilobular, panlobular, and paraseptal.

Centrilobular emphysema, the type most frequently associated with cigarette smoking, is characterized by enlarged air spaces found (initially) in association with respiratory bronchioles. Centrilobular emphysema is usually most prominent in the upper lobes and superior segments of lower lobes and is often quite focal.

Panlobular emphysema refers to abnormally large air spaces evenly distributed within and across acinar units. Panlobular emphysema is commonly observed in patients with α1AT deficiency, which has a predilection for the lower lobes.

Paraseptal emphysema occurs in 10-15% of cases and is distributed along the pleural margins with relative sparing of the lung core or central regions.

It is commonly associated with significant airway inflammation and with centrilobular emphysema.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2182

choices.text: Commonly performed for religious and cultural reasons
Symptomatic phimosis is treated by circumcision
It is protective against the spread of HIV

questions.text: All are true about the following procedure except -
questions.solution:
Recently, evidence has emerged that circumcision protects against the spread of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The virus dies quickly on a dry penis. A large-scale programme of adolescent circumcision under the auspices of the World Health Organization is ongoing in some African countries.

Circumcision is often performed for religious and cultural reasons in various parts of the world.

Physiological phimosis is a normal condition in which the foreskin cannot be retracted in young boys, and it typically resolves on its own as they grow older without the need for surgical correction.

Circumcision may be performed to treat symptomatic phimosis, a condition where the foreskin is too tight and causes discomfort or other issues.

Recent evidence suggests that circumcision can help reduce the risk of HIV transmission, especially in high-risk populations.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1548

questions.text: The following test is helpful in the identification of which organism?
questions.solution:
Bacitracin sensitivity testing

It inhibits cell wall synthesis and disrupts the cell membrane. This test is commonly used to distinguish between the hemolytic streptococci. Streptococcus agalactiae(Bacitracin resistant) and Streptococcus pyogenes(Bacitracin sensitive).

Specific zone size is given to determine bacitracin sensitive or resistant. More than or equal to 14 indicates sensitive and less than 14 is resistant.

How to perform this test - Using sterile forceps, place a bacitracin disk in the first quadrant(area of dense growth), gently tap the disk to make sure appropriate contact with the agar surface. Incubate the plate for 18 to 24 hrs at 35 degree celcius in ambient air. Observe the zone of inhibition around the disk.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition - Page no 209

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph below.
questions.solution:
Enzyme inhibition

Selective inhibition of a particular enzyme is a common mode of drug action. Such inhibition is either competitive or noncompetitive.

  • Competitive(equilibrium type) - The drug being structurally similar competes with the normal substrate for the catalytic binding site of the enzyme so that the product is not formed or a nonfunctional product is formed. Such inhibitors increase the kM but the Vmax remains unchanged.
  • A nonequilibrium type of enzyme inhibition can also occur with drugs which react with the same catalytic site of the enzyme but either form strong covalent bonds or have such high affinity for the enzyme that the normal substrate is not able to displace the inhibitor, e.g. - Organophosphates react covalently with the esteratic site of the enzyme cholinesterase. In these situations, kM is increased and Vmax is reduced. 
  • Noncompetitive - The inhibitor reacts with an adjacent site and not with the catalytic site, but alters the enzyme in such a way that it loses its catalytic property. Thus, kM is unchanged but Vmax is reduced.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p47

questions.text: A 58 year old female patient is newly diagnosed with ADPKD. Her CT Angiography is shown below. What is the finding in this image?
questions.solution:
CT angiography(CTA) of ruptured anterior cerebral artery aneurysm in a patient presenting with acute headache.

Intracranial aneurysm(ICA) occurs four to five times more frequently in ADPKD patients than in the general population and causes high mortality.

The disease gene products PC1 and PC2 may be directly responsible for defects in arterial smooth muscle cells and myofibroblasts. The focal nature and the natural history of ICA in ADPKD remain unclear.

A family history of ICA is a risk factor of aneurysm rupture in ADPKD; whether hypertension and cigarette smoking are independent risk factors is not clear. About 20–50% of patients may experience "warning headaches" preceding the index episode of subarachnoid hemorrhage due to ruptured ICA Intracranial aneurysm.

ADPKD patients with a positive family history of ICAs may undergo presymptomatic screening of ICAs by MR angiography.

Other vascular abnormalities in ADPKD patients include diffuse arterial dolichoectasia of the anterior and posterior cerebral circulation, which can predispose to arterial dissection and stroke

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2352

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient presented with upper GI bleeding. A tube has been inserted as shown below. What should be the frequency of deflating the balloons to prevent pressure necrosis?
questions.solution:
In the context of managing upper gastrointestinal(GI) bleeding with the insertion of a tube that includes balloons, it is essential to prevent pressure necrosis, a condition where excessive pressure from the balloons can cause tissue damage. To avoid this complication and allow proper blood flow to the surrounding tissues, the balloons are typically deflated at regular intervals. In this specific scenario, the recommended interval for deflating the balloons is 12 hours(option c).

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1168

questions.text: Identify the structure.
questions.solution:
The liver is a complex organ with a unique histological structure and it can be identified based on its key histological features:

Hepatocytes: Hepatocytes are the primary functional cells of the liver. They make up the majority of the liver tissue and perform various essential functions, including metabolism of nutrients, detoxification of harmful substances and synthesis of important proteins.

Sinusoids: These are specialized blood vessels found in the liver. Sinusoids have a unique structure that allows them to exchange substances between the blood and hepatocytes. They carry oxygenated and nutrient-rich blood to the hepatocytes for processing.

Bile Canaliculi: Bile canaliculi are tiny ducts between hepatocytes where bile is secreted. Bile is essential for the digestion and absorption of fats in the small intestine.

Reference: Textbook of B.D.Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No – 362

questions.text: A 33 year old female patient of rheumatoid arthritis was on DMARDs since 8 years. She revealed that she was having blurring of vision. The fundus examination revealed the features shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely drug responsible for these features?
questions.solution:
Ocular adverse-effects of drugs:

  • Amiodarone:
    • Corneal deposits(cornea verticillata)
    • Optic neuritis
  • Hydroxychloroquine:
    • Bull’s eye maculopathy(retinopathy)
  • Steroids:
    • Given topically—cause open angle glaucoma
    • Given systemically—cause posterior subcapsular cataract
  • Digoxin
    • Yellow vision

Effects of HCQ in the retina -

In the retinal pigment epithelium, accumulation of chloroquine causes a toxic retinal lesion known as a “bull’s-eye” maculopathy, which is associated with a decrease in visual acuity. To reduce the risk of retinal toxicity from chloroquine and related substances, patients receiving chronic therapy should receive periodic eye exams and lifetime cumulative doses should generally be limited to 460 g of chloroquine and 1000 g of hydroxychloroquine.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e pg 976, 1256

questions.text: A 25 year old male patient presented with nail changes. Which of the following is classically associated with this nail finding?
questions.solution:
Nail changes in Lichen planus

  • Thinning of nail plate is the most common nail finding
  • Pterygium is the most classical nail finding. Proximal nail fold fuses with proximal portion of nail bed.
  • Twenty nail dystrophy also called trachyonychia
  • Longitudinal ridging
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis
  • Pup tent sign - Elevation of nail plate in a tent like manner

Option A - Multiple small superficial pits in the nail plate which were regularly distributed in a geometric pattern along the longitudinal and transverse lines is seen in alopecia areata.

It is also known as scotch plaid pattern.

Option C - Onychomycosis can be dermatophytic and non dermatophytic

There are four types of dermatophyte onychomycosis -

  • Distal subungual onychomycosis (DSO) is the most common form of onychomycosis. It is characterized by invasion of the nail bed and underside of the nail plate beginning at the hyponychium
  • Proximal subungual onychomycosis (PSO). It is common in AIDS
  • White superficial onychomycosis (WSO)
  • Total dystrophic nail

Option D - Onychomadesis is seen in pemphigus vulgaris. Onychomadesis is the proximal separation of the nail plate from the nail matrix due to a temporary cessation of nail growth

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition, page 730

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy comes with the complaint of chronic coughing for the last 3 months and exercise induced wheezing. His barium swallow is shown below. What is the most probable cause of his coughing?
questions.solution:
The barium swallow demonstrates a vascular ring – most probably an anomalous origin of the subclavian artery. Examples of vascular rings include double aortic arches, a right aortic arch with a ligamentum arteriosum and(as in this case) an anomalous origin of the right subclavian artery.

The vessel takes a retropharyngeal or esophageal route, causing compression of the esophagus and trachea. Symptoms include stridor, a persistent cough or wheeze. Dysphagia is more likely in older children. The diagnosis may be confirmed with a contrast CT scan of the chest with or without bronchoscopy.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2237

questions.text: A 35 year old male chronic alcoholic and I.V drug user was newly diagnosed with HIV 3months ago. At present, the patient has a complaint of fever, cough, weight loss and anorexia. His HRCT is shown below. Which of the following is a false statement regarding this?
questions.solution:
Miliary TB is due to hematogenous spread of tubercle bacilli. Although in children it is often the conse of primary infection, in adults it may be due to either recent  infection or reactivation of old disseminated foci. The lesions are usually yellowish granulomas 1–2mm in diameter that resemble millet seeds.

Clinical manifestations are nonspecific and protean, depending on the predominant site of involvement. Fever, night sweats, anorexia, weakness and weight loss are presenting symptoms in the majority of cases. At times, patients have a cough and other respiratory symptoms due to pulmonary involvement as well as abdominal symptoms.

Physical findings include hepatomegaly, splenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Eye examination may reveal choroidal tubercles, which are pathognomonic of miliary TB, in up to 30% of cases. Meningismus occurs in fewer than 10% of cases.

Frequently, CXR  reveals a miliary reticulonodular pattern(more easily seen on underpenetrated film), although no radiographic abnormality may be evident early in the course and among HIV infected patients.

Other radiologic findings include large infiltrates, interstitial infiltrates(especially in HIV-infected patients), and pleural effusion.

Sputum-smear microscopy is negative in most cases. Various hematologic abnormalities may be seen, including anemia with leukopenia, lymphopenia, neutrophilic leukocytosis and leukemoid reactions, and polycythemia. Disseminated intravascular coagulation has been reported.

Elevation of alkaline phosphatase levels and other abnormal values in liver function tests are detected in patients with severe hepatic involvement. TST results may be negative in up to half of cases, but reactivity may be restored during chemotherapy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 1367

questions.text: According to the Bosniak classification of renal cysts, which type of cyst is shown below?
questions.solution:
The Bosniak classification is a system used to categorize renal cysts based on their appearance on imaging studies, such as computed tomography(CT) scans. Bosniak IV cysts are the most concerning category, as they have features that suggest a high likelihood of malignancy or the presence of a cancerous lesion. Therefore, when a renal cyst is classified as Bosniak IV, it often requires close monitoring or surgical intervention for further evaluation and potential treatment.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1461

questions.text: A known HIV pt on anti retroviral therapy presented with diarrhea of six months duration. Stool microscopy was done in which 10-30 micrometer cysts were seen. Knyoun stain was positive. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
HIV is an immunocompromised condition, many opportunistic infections occur in it.

Diarrhea is one of the symptoms due to opportunistic infection.

Cryptosporidium parvum, Cystoisospora belli etc  causes diarrhea in immuno compromised condition.

Cystoisospora

  • Infective form – oocyst(Contain four sporozoite)
  • Oocyst is 25-30 microns in size.
  • Principal site of infection – small intestine
  • In patients with AIDS, involvement of biliary tract can cause papillary stenosis, sclerosing cholangitis or cholecystitis.

Cryptosporidium parvum oocyst is smaller 4 -5 micron in size.

Strongyloides does not produce acid fast oocyst as shown in the image

B coli also does not produce acid fast oocyst as shown in the image

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition - Page no 91,92

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image?
questions.solution:
Contact leukoderma can occur over chronic exposure of chemicals

Option C - Oculocutaneous albinism:

Oculocutaneous albinism(OCA) is a group of inherited disorders of melanin biosynthesis due to defect in tyrosinase characterized by a generalized reduction in pigmentation of hair, skin and eyes.

A single patch to be used for 3 weeks

questions.text: The given figure shows a transdermal patch used for contraceptive purposes. The patch is not yet available in India. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the patch?
questions.solution:
The figure shows a transdermal patch - Ortho Evra.

This is a combination transdermal patch delivering norelgestromin and ethinyl oestradiol and is not yet available in India.

The patch has a surface area of 20cu.cm and delivers a daily dose of 150mg of norelgestromin and 20mg of ethinyl estradiol. It can be worn for 7days.

Hence three patches are used for three weeks with a patch-free interval in the fourth week. The contraindications and side effects are similar to the COC. Good cycle control is there.

The major advantage compared to the COC is that compliance is better. The disadvantage is patch detachment.

Reference: Textbook Of Gynaecology by Sheila Balakrishnan, 3rd edition, page no 352

questions.solution:

choices.text: This technique allows ventilation for periods in excess of 1 hour
A 14 or 16 gauge plastic sheathed intravascular needle is used
Multiple cannulae can be utilized as exhalation ports.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the procedure seen below -
questions.solution:
This technique is simple and effective and allows ventilation for periods in excess of 1 hour, providing time to allow for more elective intubation.

The cricothyroid membrane is pierced by a 14 or 16 gauge plastic sheathed intra- vascular needle attached to a 10-mL syringe containing a few milliliters of lidocaine and is introduced in the midline and directed downwards and backwards into the tracheal lumen.

The needle is advanced steadily and negative pressure is placed on the syringe until bubbles of air are clearly seen.

The tissues of the neck may be infiltrated with the anesthetic if desired and the tracheal mucosa likewise partly anesthetized by the introduction of 1–2mL of lidocaine after gaining the lumen.

The needle is removed and the plastic sheath cannula left in the tracheal lumen; it must be carefully held and fixed in place by the operator so that it does not come out of the lumen into the soft tissues of the neck. It is attached by means of a Luer connection to the high-pressure oxygen supply.

Ventilation may be undertaken in a controlled manner with a jetting device, with the chest being observed for appropriate movements.

If there is severe obstruction of the laryngopharynx by a foreign body or a tumor, the exhaled outflow of gases can be aided by the placement of one or two further cannulae as exhalation ports. This procedure gains extremely rapid control of ventilation and requires a minimum of technical expertise.

Its only notable complication is surgical emphysema of the neck tissues if the cannula dislodged from the tracheal lumen.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 799

Congenital vaginal agenesis is associated with all of the following, except -
questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the type of inheritance in the given pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
• From the chart we can see that female parents are carriers for the disease. The male parent is unaffected.
  • Let us denote the allele as 'F'. The mother's genotype will be Ff since she is a carrier. The father can be either FF or Ff.
  • In the first generation, we see that none of the offspring are affected.
  • Out of the five offspring, three are carriers and two are unaffected. This indicates that the father's genotype is FF.
  • This also tells us that the gene is recessive. If it was a dominant trait, it would have shown in the offspring.
  • Also, both male and female children are carriers, indicating that the trait is not sex linked.
  • That means the pedigree chart shows an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • In the second generation again, we see that in one family father is a carrier and mother is unaffected. For these parents one daughter is a carrier(Ff) and one daughter is unaffected(FF). From this we can make out that the father is heterozygous(Ff) for the trait and the mother is homozygous dominant(FF). For the second family, we see that both mother and father are carriers, so both of them are heterozygous for the trait(Ff). Out of the five offspring, two are carriers(one boy and one girl), two are affected(one boy and one girl) and one boy is unaffected. Thus, we can infer that the trait is autosomal recessive in nature.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles Of Internal Medicine 21st edition chapter 466, page 3652.

questions.text: A 67 year old female patient was prescribed the drug X for osteoporosis. Based on the mechanism shown in the below figure drug X is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Denosumab: It is a fully human monoclonal antibody against RANKL. By binding to and neutralizing RANKL, denosumab prevents RANK activation thereby inhibiting proliferation and differentiation of osteoclast precursors as well as osteoclast function.

As a result, bone resorption is inhibited to an extent equal to or greater than potent BPNs. It is now being used as a treatment option for osteoporosis in both women and men, as well as to limit bony metastasis in breast and prostate cancers.

In osteoporotic patients with high fracture risk, denosumab has been found to lower vertebral as well as hip fracture risk by 40–68%. It can be given to patients with severe renal disease, in whom BPNs are contraindicated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e pg. 371

questions.text: A 28 yrs old female patient presented to opd with complain of right breast lump. On triple assesment of breast, there was a right breast giant fibroadenoma, which was operated by incision given below. Name of this incision?
questions.solution:
For the removal of a giant fibroadenoma from the right breast, surgeons may use either a "Submammary incision" or a "Gaillard Thomas incision". Both of these incisions are commonly employed in breast surgery, and the choice between them depends on the specific characteristics of the fibroadenoma and the patient's anatomy.

Submammary Incision: This incision is made below the breast, in the inframammary fold. It provides good access to the breast tissue and is often used for various breast surgeries, including fibroadenoma removal.

Gaillard Thomas Incision: This incision is made around the areola(the dark area around the nipple) and is useful for surgeries involving the areola and nipple. It allows for inconspicuous scarring when the fibroadenoma is closer to the nipple.

Since both incisions can be suitable for giant fibroadenoma removal, the correct answer is (d) Both 'B' and 'C' because both "Submammary incision" and "Gaillard Thomas incision" are valid choices.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 922

choices.text: Represents a major degree of placenta praevia
A patient with this condition should be allowed a short trial of labour
The patient with this condition should be delivered by elective Cesarean section
It is always complicated by post-partum hemorrhage

questions.text: Regarding the given picture, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
• Definition: Placentra praevia is defined as a placenta located partly or completely in the lower uterine segment. The bleeding is called inevitable or unavoidable haemorrhage as dilatation of the internal os inevitably results in haemorrhage.

Placenta previa

  • Type 1 and 2 are called minor degrees and type 3 and 4 called major degrees of placenta previa.
  • Type 1 and 2 can be anterior or posterior.
  • Type 2 posterior placenta is also called the ‘dangerous type’ as it is more likely to be compressed producing cord compression. This can cause fetal asphyxia and even death.
  • Newer classification -
    • Placenta Previa: The internal os is covered partially or completely by placenta. In the past, these were further classified as either total or partial previa.
    • Low-lying placenta: Implantation in the lower uterine segment is such that the placental edge does not reach the internal os and remains outside a 2cm wide perimeter around the os. A previously used term, marginal previa, described a placenta that was at the edge of the internal os but did not overlie it.

Ref: JB Sharma textbook of gynecology e9 pg 809

questions.text: The given image shows which type of fracture?
questions.solution:
This is a simple dent of the skull, which results from an obstetric forceps blade, a blow from a blunt object or forcible impact against some protruding object. They occur only in skulls of infants. The inner table is not fractured, but fissured fractures may occur in the outer table around the periphery of the dent.

Reference: Pg 246, 33rd edition, THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the marked muscle?
questions.solution:
It is the cricothyroid muscle.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies posterior cricoarytenoid, lateral cricoarytenoid, transverse and oblique arytenoid, aryepiglottic, thyroarytenoid, thyroepiglottic muscles. It supplies all intrinsic muscles except cricothyroid.

External laryngeal nerve only supplies cricothyroid muscle.


Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume- 3, 8th Edition, Page No- 292, 293

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient presented with skin lesions over neck and hands. He was an alcoholic. Which micronutrient deficiency can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
Pellagra is a systemic disease caused by vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency. It is characterized by the 4 D'sdermatitis, diarrhea, dementia and, if untreated death.

Dermatitis occurs over the photo exposed sites of the body. Eczematous lesions over the neck also known as 'Casal's necklace'.

Pellagra is a disease of a maize and jowar-eating population. Amino-acid imbalance caused by an excess of leucine is the cause of pellagra in both jowar and maize eaters. Excess of leucine appears to interfere in the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

Malabsorption syndromes (jejunoileitis, gastroenterostomy, subtotal gastrectomy, Crohn's disease), chronic alcoholism, metabolic derangements (Hartnup disease, carcinoid syndrome), and drugs (INH, 6-mercaptopurine, 5-fluorouracil, pyrazinamide, phenytoin, chloramphenicol, azathioprine, phenobarbitone, ethionamide) are the causes of pellagra.

Reference: IADVL textbook of dermatology, 4th edition, page 251

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presents with numbness over the thumb, index and middle finger. Her clinical photograph is given below. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical photograph of both hands showing bilateral thenar eminence wasting. In conjunction with the history, the most likely diagnosis is carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), that is caused by compression of the median nerve in at the carpal tunnel.

It is more common in females 6:1 males and is bilateral in 40% cases.

Most of the cases of CTS are idiopathic (pathological synovium), although there are a large number of recognised predisposing factors:

  • Fluid retention
    • Diabetes
    • Pregnancy
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Renal failure
    • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Obesity
  • Inflammatory arthropathies
  • Space occupying lesions
    • Lipoma
    • Ganglion

Reference: essential orthopedics manish kumar Varshney 1st edition page no 1696

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient complains of headache and difficulty in walking. He consulted a neurologist and he had undergone an MRI brain, which is shown below. Which of the following is not a clinical feature of his disease?
questions.solution:
The MRI shows -

  • Sagittal T1-weighted MRI demonstrates dilation of the lateral ventricle and stretching of the corpus callosum (arrows), depression of the floor of the third ventricle (single arrowhead), and enlargement of the aqueduct (double arrowheads). Note the diffuse dilation of the lateral, third, and fourth ventricles with a patent aqueduct, typical of communicating hydrocephalus.
  • Axial T2-weighted MRIs demonstrate dilation of the lateral ventricles.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is a relatively uncommon but treatable syndrome. The clinical, physiologic, and neuroimaging characteristics of NPH must be carefully distinguished from those of other dementias associated with gait impairment.

For NPH, the clinical triad includes -

  • abnormal gait (ataxic or apractic)
  • dementia (usually mild to moderate, with an emphasis on executive impairment)
  • urinary urgency or incontinence.

Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures may appear propped open (so-called boxcarring), which can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy.

Crowding of dorsal frontal-parietal gyri helps distinguish NPH from other movement disorders, such as PSP and CBD, in which dorsal atrophy with sulcal widening is common.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 194,3375

choices.text: Dealing with a 'dog ear' at the corner of an elliptical incision

questions.text: What is the following procedure used for?
questions.solution:
The procedure described, "Dealing with a 'dog ear' at the corner of an elliptical incision," is typically used in plastic surgery or dermatology. When an elliptical incision is made for the removal of a skin lesion, such as a mole or a tumor, sometimes there can be a folding or bunching of the skin at the corners of the incision, which resembles a "dog ear." Surgeons use specific techniques to address this issue and create a smoother, more cosmetically pleasing wound closure.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 99

Although both are difficult to differentiate on HSG, there are a few ways by which they can be differentiated.

Angle between the 2 hours is more than 60°, hence it is an HSG of a bicornuate uterus.

choices.text: Medial inferior pontine syndrome is due to occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery
Nystagmus is due to involvement of the Vestibular nucleus
Ataxia of limbs and gait is Likely due to involvement of the middle cerebellar peduncle
Diplopia on lateral gaze is due to Abducens nerve palsy

questions.text: The following picture shows pontine syndrome. What is false regarding the medial inferior pontine syndrome according to the involved structure?
questions.solution:
Medial inferior pontine syndrome (occlusion of paramedian branch of basilar artery)

On the side of the lesion -

  • Paralysis of conjugate gaze to side of lesion (preservation of convergence): Center for conjugate lateral gaze
  • Nystagmus: Vestibular nucleus
  • Ataxia of limbs and gait: Likely middle cerebellar peduncle
  • Diplopia on lateral gaze: Abducens nerve
  • Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia: Vestibular nerve or nucleus
  • Facial paralysis: Seventh nerve
  • Paralysis of conjugate gaze to side of lesion: Center for conjugate lateral gaze
  • Deafness, tinnitus: Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus
  • Ataxia: Middle cerebellar peduncle and cerebellar hemisphere
  • Impaired sensation over face: Descending tract and nucleus fifth nerve

On the side opposite to the lesion -

  • Paralysis of face, arm, and leg: Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract in lower pons
  • Impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense over one-half of the body: Medial lemniscus
  • Lateral inferior pontine syndrome (occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery)
  • Impaired pain and thermal sense over one-half the body (may include face): Spinothalamic tract

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition- Page 3330

questions.text:
Match the following.

1. Nissen 360°
2. Dor anterior fundoplication
3. Nirmal anatomy
4. Toupet posterior fundoplication
questions.solution:
The matching of surgical procedures with their descriptions is as follows:

  • Nissen 360° fundoplication: This surgical procedure involves a complete 360-degree wrap of the fundus of the stomach around the esophagus. It is commonly used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Dor anterior fundoplication: This procedure is a partial fundoplication used to treat GERD. It involves wrapping a portion of the stomach around the esophagus.
  • Normal anatomy: This refers to the typical anatomical structure without any surgical alterations.
  • Toupet posterior fundoplication: This procedure is a partial fundoplication used to treat GERD. It involves wrapping the posterior aspect of the stomach around the esophagus.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1116

questions.text: The given ultrasound is suggestive of what type of twin gestattion?

Note the thick dividing membrane and wedge-shaped "lambda sign," the area at the top of the image, which represents the junction of the 2 placentae.

questions.text: Based on the mechanism of action the drug Z shown in the below figure is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The figure shows the mechanism of drug action to be sodium glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibition. This is done by canagliflozin, dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. These drugs are approved for use in type 2 DM patients. After once daily dosing, they produce round-the-clock glucosuria and lower blood glucose levels. Used alone or in combination with other antidiabetic drugs, they reduce HbA1C levels by 0.5-1.0%.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p301

questions.text: The following image shows the schematic diagrams of the configurational changes in carotid pulse. What is your diagnosis from the given image?
questions.solution:
A weak and delayed pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus) defines severe aortic stenosis (AS). Some patients with AS may also have a slow, notched, or interrupted upstroke (anacrotic pulse) with a thrill or shudder. Anacrotic pulse with slow upstroke to a reduced peak is seen.

Bisferiens pulse with two peaks in systole. This pulse is rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Bisferiens pulse in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 1819

choices.text: A toe-brachial pressure index (TBI) with an ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a more reliable diagnostic tool for the detection of significant large-vessel steno-occlusive disease in patients with DM.
A TBI less than 0.6 suggests a significant arterial lesion.
There are no limitations to the usage of TBI in the DM population
One in six patients with DM presenting with chronic limb threatening ischemia will have gangrene or will have undergone an amputation of the hallux.

questions.text: All are true about the test being performed below, except -
questions.solution:
The digital arteries of the ties are rarely affected by sclerosis and a toe-brachial pressure index (TBI) in combination with ABI is advocated as a more reliable diagnostic tool for the detection of significant large-vessel steno-occlusive disease in patients with DM.

A TBI less than 0.6 suggests a significant arterial lesion that may have been overlooked if ABI was used in isolation. However, there are limitations to the usage of TBI in the DM population, one in six patients with DM presenting with chronic limb threatening ischemia (CLTI) will have gangrene or will have undergone an amputation of the hallux.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1001

questions.solution:
The pessary shown is the Hodge pessary. It is used for treating retroversion.

Indications of Hodge Pessary -

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the fracture shown in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows fracture of scaphoid. The most important complications are as follows:

  • Avascular necrosis: The blood supply of the scaphoid is precarious. In fractures through the waist, there is a high probability of the proximal fragment becoming avascular. The patient complains of pain and weakness of the wrist. On the X-ray one finds non-union of the fracture with sclerosis and crushing of the proximal pole of the scaphoid. It is a difficult problem to treat. If the patient is symptomatic, the avascular segment of the bone is excised. In some cases, the wrist may develop osteoarthritis.
  • Delayed and non-union: A high proportion of cases of fractures of the scaphoid go into delayed or non-union. More than one factor contributes to this. It may be because of imperfect immobilisation, the synovial fluid hindering the formation of fibrinous bridge between the fragments, or impaired blood supply to one of the fragments.
  • Wrist osteoarthritis: In some cases of scaphoid fractures, osteoarthritis of the wrist develops as a result of avascular necrosis or non-union. Treatment depends upon the symptoms. Conservative treatment with hot fomentation and physiotherapy is sufficient in most cases. In some, excision of the styloid process of the radius; or in extreme cases, wrist arthrodesis may be required.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition - Page no:116.

questions.text: What procedure is shown below?
questions.solution:
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) is a minimally invasive procedure used to visualize and sample tissues and lymph nodes in the mediastinum (the area between the lungs) and within the bronchial walls. It is often used for the staging and diagnosis of lung cancer and other thoracic conditions.




Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 982 , 987

questions.text: Which of the following drug is likely to act by signal transduction mechanism shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Phospholipase C: IP3-DAG pathway -

  • Activation of phospholipase Cβ (PLcβ) by the activated GTP carrying α subunit of Gq hydrolyses the membrane phospholipid phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) to generate the second messengers inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG).
  • The IP3 being water soluble diffuses to the cytosol and mobilizes Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticular depots. The lipophilic DAG remains within the membrane, but recruits protein kinase C (PKc) and activates it with the help of Ca2+. Triggered by IP3, the released Ca2+ (third messenger in this setting) acts as a highly versatile regulator.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p57

questions.text: The most common site of obstetric injury leading to a uretero vaginal fistula is shown by which numerical in the image?
questions.solution:
The crossing of the uterine vessels and ureter is at the level of internal os. Over here the ureter runs below the uterine vessels (water below the bridge) and the distance between the ureter and uterine vessels is only 1.5-2 cm.

The ureter can get injured at all the sites mentioned in the question but during gynecological surgeries the commonest site of injury to ureter is where it crosses below the uterine arteries.

The next common site of injury is behind the infundibulopelvic ligament at the pelvic brim.

Incidence: 0.5-1% of all pelvic operations.

  • Sites
    • At or below the pelvic brim (I)
    • Along the course of ureter on lateral pelvic wall above the uterosacral ligaments (II)
    • In the base of broad ligament where the ureter passes beneath the uterine vessels, about 1.5 cm lateral to cervix at the level of internal orifice (III)
    • Beyond the uterine vessels as the ureter passes in the tunnel in Mackenrodt’s ligament and turns anteriorly and medially to enter the bladder (IV)
    • In the intramural portion of the bladder (V)

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 15th Edition - Page no 174

choices.text: The ST segment plus the T wave and the U wave represent ventricular repolarization
The QRS interval reflects the duration of ventricular depolarization
The PR interval measures the time between atrial and ventricular depolarization

questions.text: The following image shows a normal ECG and its waves and intervals. Which of the following is a false statement regarding this?
questions.solution:
The ECG waveforms are labeled alphabetically, beginning with the P wave, which represents atrial depolarization.

The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization, and the ST-T-U complex (ST segment, T wave, and U wave) represents ventricular repolarization.

The J point is the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment. Atrial repolarization waveforms (ST-Ta ) are usually of too low in amplitude to be detected, but they may become apparent in acute pericarditis, atrial infarction, and AV heart block.

There are four major sets of ECG intervals: RR, PR, QRS, and QT/QTc (Fig. 240-2). The instantaneous heart rate (beats per minute) can be computed from the interbeat (RR) interval by dividing the number of large (0.20 s) time units between consecutive R waves into 300 or the number of small (40ms) segments into 1500.

The PR interval measures the time (normally 120-20ms) between atrial and ventricular depolarization, which includes the physiologic delay imposed by stimulation of cells in the AV junction area.

The QRS interval (normally 100-110ms or less) reflects the duration of ventricular depolarization.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 1824

choices.text: Fitz-Curtis-Hugh Syndrome is a complication of this condition
Characteristic findings at laparoscopy are diagnostic
Pelvic abscess results from secondary invasion by anaerobic organisms
Bacterial vaginosis is a known aetiological factor

questions.text: This is a laparoscopic view of the pelvis in a patient with pelvic inflammatory disease. Which is a false statement regarding this?
questions.solution:
Criteria for the Diagnosis of PID

  • Definitive Criteria
    • Histopathological evidence of endometritis on endometrial biopsy
    • Tubo-ovarian abscess on sonography or other radiologic tests
    • Laparoscopic abnormalities consistent with PID
  • Additional Criteria
    • Oral temperature more than 38.3°C (101°F)
    • Abnormal cervical or vaginal mucopurulent discharge
    • Presence of abundant WBC on saline mount of vaginal secretions
    • ESR > 15 mm/hours
    • Elevated C-reactive protein
    • Laboratory documentation of cervical infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Minimum Criteria
    • Lower abdominal tenderness or
    • Adnexal tenderness
    • Cervical motion tenderness.
  • CDC Guidelines for treatment of PID
  • Sequelae of PID
    • Infertility - seen in 6-60% patients
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia
    • Fitz-hugh-Curtis syndrome

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of gynecology - 7th edition - Page no 128

questions.text: A 7-day old girl born at 28 weeks of gestation, is on artificial ventilation. Surfactant has been given. There is sudden deterioration in the clinical condition. An X ray chest was done as follows. What is the cause of deterioration?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of mediastinal shift with sharp margins of air. These are suggestive of pneumothorax.

The child was on ventilation support which always has risk of pneumothorax that presents as sudden deterioration.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2136

questions.text: Following lesion is caused by which organism?
questions.solution:
This is a buruli ulcer, caused by M ulcerans.

It is a rare and exotic bacterial infection of the skin and soft tissue. Buruli ulcer is caused by infections with the organism mycobacterium ulcerans, it is found mainly in tropical areas, including west Africa and Australia.

It starts as a painless swelling of the affected area, which is usually the arms, legs or face. Large ulcer eventually develops.

Mosquito bite and puncture wounds are likely to transmit bacteria causing buruli ulcer.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition - Page no 360

questions.text: A 25 yr old female patient presented to opd with complain of lump in the right breast which was freely movable in the breast tissue. On ultrasonography shows a well - circumscribed solid mass in this young woman, which is given below. What is the BIRADS score of this patient ?
questions.solution:
The BIRADS score (Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System) is a system used to categorize and report findings on breast imaging studies, such as mammograms and ultrasounds. Here's an explanation of the BIRADS scores:

  • BIRADS 0: Incomplete assessment, additional imaging or evaluation is needed.
  • BIRADS 1: Negative, no signs of breast cancer.
  • BIRADS 2: Benign finding, there is a very low suspicion of breast cancer.
  • BIRADS 3: Probably benign, follow-up is recommended.
  • BIRADS 4: Suspicious abnormality, a biopsy is usually recommended.
  • BIRADS 5: Highly suggestive of malignancy, further evaluation and biopsy are needed.

In this case, the patient has a well-circumscribed solid mass in the breast that is freely movable, which is less likely to be cancerous. Therefore, the appropriate BIRADS score would be (d) BIRADS 3, indicating that further follow-up or evaluation is recommended to confirm the benign nature of the mass.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 916

questions.text: What is the given image showing?
questions.solution:
NUCHAL TRANSLUCENCY -

Increased nuchal translucency (≥3 mm) can be associated with a number of anomalies, including:

  • Aneuploidy-trisomies (including Down's syndrome) and Turner's syndrome
  • Non Aneuploidy structural defects and syndromes
    • congenital diaphragmatic hernia
    • congenital heart disease,
    • omphalocele
    • skeletal dysplasia
    • fetal infections

The detection rate of about 75-80% can be obtained by screening of fetuses by NT alone with maternal age for trisomy 21 and other major aneuploidies with a false positive rate of 5%.

The detection rate can be improved to 90% by a combination of NT with maternal serum free β-hCG and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A).

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics - 7th edition - Page no 188

questions.solution:

questions.text: Identify the type of disc prolapse shown in the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The nucleus pulposus of the disc is under positive pressure at all times. When the annulus becomes weak, either because a small area of its entire thickness has disintegrated spontaneously or because of injury, the nucleus tends to bulge through the defect This is called disc protrusion.

This tendency is greatly increased if the nucleus is degenerated and fragmented. Finally, the nucleus comes out of the annulus and lies under the posterior longitudinal ligament; though it has not lost contact with the parent disc. This is called disc extrusion.

Once extruded, the disc does not go back. The posterior longitudinal ligament is not strong enough to prevent the nucleus from protruding further. The extruded disc may lose its contact with the parent disc, when it is called a sequestrated disc.

The sequestrated disc may come to lie behind the posterior longitudinal ligament or may become free fragment in the canal.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition - Page no:253

questions.text: 72-year-old man is referred by his family physician for evaluation of decreasing vision and increasing erythema of the right eye over the last 24 hours. The patient also has had pain of the right scalp and several new "pimples" on his forehead. The appearance of the right eye is shown in the figure. Which of the following is the least likely ocular finding in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has herpes zoster of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (herpes zoster ophthalmicus). The ipsilateral eye becomes involved about 50% of the time. When skin eruptions involve the tip of the nose (Hutchinson's sign), there is a greater likelihood of ocular involvement. Myositis may impede motility of the globe. A follicular reaction of the conjunctiva is common. The iridocyclitis or trabeculitis that may occur with zoster often results in elevation of the intraocular pressure. Other forms of secondary glaucoma are possible, including hemorrhagic glaucoma. The retina or optic nerve may become involved 2 to 3 weeks after the initial onset of the skin rash, but pars planitis has not previously been associated with this disorder.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology 9th edition pg.224

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl gets admitted with generalized tonic clonic seizure, first episode. On examination there are typical features as follows. She must undergo all the following investigation as a routine except -
questions.solution:
The child in the image shows hypomelanotic macule, facial angiofibroma and shagreen patch. This satisfies the diagnostic criteria for Tuberous sclerosis.

The disease is heterogeneous with a wide spectrum of clinical presentation ranging from severe mental retardation and frequent seizures to normal intelligence and lack of seizures. Characteristic 'tubers' may be located in the subependymal regions of the brain and may undergo calcification.

Other anomalies may also be found in the heart (rhabdomyoma), kidneys (hamartoma), eyes (optic nerve mulberry tumor and/or retinal phakoma), lungs (angiomyolipoma) and bone.

Skin abnormalities include hypo- or hyperpigmented areas, sebaceous adenomas over the cheeks and nose, and shagreen patches typically over the lumbar region. Subungual fibromas may be found around toenails and fingernails.

Hypopigmented areas are best identified using Woods light (UV light source).

CT and MRI brain scans identify cerebral anomalies.

EEG may demonstrate hypsarrhythmia, particularly where presentation is in infancy in the context of infantile spasms. Echocardiogram will identify cardiac lesions.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2878

questions.text: A 36 year old female with Graves disease was on medication for hyperthyroidism throughout the pregnancy. She delivered a child with scalp defects as shown below. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated for this teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
All Antithyroid drugs (carbimazole, methimazole, propylthiouracil) if taken during pregnancy can cause fetal hypothyroidism, congenital goiter, scalp defects (aplasia cutis congenita)

Use of antithyroid drugs in pregnancy may result in:

  • Fetal hypothyroidism
  • Aplasia cutis
  • Scalp or patchy hair defect
  • Choanal atresia
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Tracheo-esophageal fistula
  • Minor facial anomalies
  • Hypoplastic or absent phalanges
  • Psychomotor delay

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e p797

questions.text: A 34 year old female patient had dizziness and palpitations. On admission, her BP was 122/82 mmHg. Which of the following is the correct intervention?
questions.solution:
ECG in lead II shows heart rate of >200 bpm and narrow QRS complexes are present.

Global ST depression is present in all leads and the P wave is hidden in QRS complexes.

The interpretation is PSVT and since the patient is hemodynamically stable, adenosine is used for chemical cardioversion.

Option A- is used in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

Option D- is used in the management of STEMI.

Option C- is used in the management of ventricular tachycardia.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 1895

questions.text: Which of the following congenital cataract is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
CONGENITAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL CATARACTS

This is due to disturbance in the growth and development of the lens. Disturbance in development during the period of gestation leads to congenital cataract and usually affects the embryonic or foetal nucleus. Developmental cataract is due to disturbance in development after birth and hence affects the infantile or adult nucleus and cortex. The different morphological varieties are -

  • Punctate cataract: It consists of minute white dots throughout the lens but causes no visual disturbance. It is called blue dot cataract. It is the most common type of congenital cataract.
  • Zonular or lamellar cataract: This is the most common type of congenital cataract associated with diminished vision. A zone in the foetal nucleus is usually affected. Hypocalcemia in pregnancy is an important cause.
  • Nuclear cataract- This usually affects the embryonic nucleus. Rubella in pregnancy is an important cause.
  • Coronary cataract. It usually occurs around puberty of and is characterized by opacities in the periphery of the lens.
  • Anterior polarcataract
  • Posterior polar cataract

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 6th edition - Page no 415

questions.text: Following a urinary tract infection, a 3-year-old child underwent a micturating cystourethrogram. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented to the eye opd following blunt trauma by wood. On detailed fundus examination, retinal dialysis as shown in image below was found. In which of the following quadrants is retinal dialysis most often found following blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
Blunt trauma may result in a variety of retinal breaks including retinal dialyses, macular holes, giant retinal tears, horseshoe retinal tears, operculated retinal tears, and large, necrotic, sometimes posterior retinal breaks often associated with chorioretinitis sclopetaria.

Retinal dialyses, however, are the most common retinal breaks found following blunt ocular trauma. Retinal dialyses resulting from blunt trauma are most often found in the inferotemporal and superonasal quadrants. All patients with a history of blunt trauma need to be given a careful retinal examination with scleral depression to look for retinal breaks after their pain, iritis, or hyphema, if any, has resolved.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology 9th edition pg.666 and pg.904

questions.text: A 5-day-old 36-week-gestation infant was born by spontaneous vaginal delivery after prolonged rupture of membranes for 3 days and was commenced on formula feed. On the 5th day following birth the infant starts vomiting bile-stained material and develops abdominal distension. The infant undergoes a full septic screen, feeds are stopped and she is started on antibiotics. Initial results show - CRP 45 mg/l, Hb 18.2 g/dl, WBC count 20,000/mm3 and platelets 2.02L/mm3. What diagnosis is the abdominal X-ray consistent with?
questions.solution:
The abdominal X-rays demonstrate dilated loops of bowel. The clinical features suggest inflammation and sepsis consistent with necrotizing enterocolitis.

Bilious vomiting in the first 24 hours of life is more likely to have a surgical cause.

Risk of sepsis due to prolonged rupture of membrane, introduction of powdered milk also a risk factor for NEC and blood investigation suggestive of sepsis supports the X ray finding of NEC.

The treatment is conservative and supportive unless it gets ruptured, which needs an urgent surgical repair.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 869

questions.text: A patient from Bihar with hypopigmented and normoaesthetic patches on the back (image given). He gave history of long term fever in his child hood. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PKDL (Post kala azar dermal leishmaniasis) is a complication of visceral leishmaniasis (VL).

It is characterized by a macular, maculo papular and nodular rash in a patient who has recovered from VL and who is otherwise well. The rash usually starts around the mouth from where it spreads to other parts of the body depending on its severity. It is mainly seen in Sudan and India, where it follows treated VL in 50 % and 5-10 % cases.

It is largely restricted to areas where L. donovani is the main parasite causing VL. The interval at PKDL follows VL is 0-6 months in Sudan and 2-3 years in india.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition - Page no 214

questions.text: An investigational Benzodiazepine analogue is being evaluated for its hypnotic action with respect to the safety. From the information provided in the figure below, find the therapeutic index of the investigational drug:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 = 40/10 = 4

questions.text: A 36-year-old G1P0 woman presents for her first prenatal visit late in her first trimester of pregnancy. She complains of persistent vaginal bleeding, nausea, and pelvic pain. Physical examination is notable for a gravid uterus larger than expected for gestational age. Fetal heart tones are absent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given question, the patient is presenting late in her first trimester of pregnancy with complaints of persistent vaginal bleeding, nausea, and pelvic pain. Physical examination is notable for a gravid uterus larger than expected for gestational age. Fetal heart tones are absent.

Twin pregnancy can be ruled out because it does not explain persistent vaginal bleeding and moreover in twin/multiple pregnancy fetal heart tones are not absent, rather 2 or more FHS are heard depending on the number of fetuses.

Concealed variety of APH does not occur in the late first trimester. APH by definition means any bleeding which occurs after 28 weeks of pregnancy and uptil the birth of the child and hence it can be ruled out although absent fetal tones and Fundal height more than the gestational age are seen.

Polyhydramnios again can be ruled out since bleeding cannot be explained by it.

The USG shown in the plate is the typical snow storm appearance. Hence, the diagnosis is confirmed.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics - 7th edition - Page no 888

questions.text: A patient is trying to stand up as shown in the figure. Which of the following muscles is paralyzed?
questions.solution:
When the gluteus maximus is paralyzed as in muscular dystrophy, the patient cannot stand up from a sitting posture without support.

Such patients, while trying to stand up, rise gradually, supporting their hands first on legs and then on the thighs; they climb on themselves.

Testing gluteus maximus the patient lies prone. The right hand of the physician presses the patient's right leg downwards. Patient is requested to extend his hip against resistance provided by the physician's right hand; while his left hand feels the contracting gluteus maximus muscle.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No - 81

questions.text: Fungal hyphae with acute angled branching and septate hyphae as shown are
questions.solution:
Angled branched and septate hyphae are seen in Aspergillus spp. Aspergillus has many species but A niger, A fumigatus and A. flavus causes most diseases in humans.

Septate hyphae are seen in zygomycetes. Septate and aseptate are the distinguishing features in microscopy.

questions.text: What treponema is seen in the silver impregnation micrograph below?
questions.solution:
Hook like appearance of the spirochete in the dark field microscopy image is suggestive of Leptospira infection.

Leptospira is associated with 3 R's

  • Rat
  • Rice field
  • Rain

Leptospirosis is the most widespread zoonosis.

High risk groups -

  • Farmers
  • Sewage workers
  • Workers in the fishing industry
  • Veterinarians.

Lab diagnosis

  • Increase ESR
  • Leukocytosis
  • Mild thrombocytopenia
  • Increased serum bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase.
  • Increased prothrombin time
  • BUN and creatinine may be raised

Isolation of organism is done on the following media -

  • EMJH medium
  • Fletcher medium
  • Korthof medium
  • Stuart medium

Serological tests -

  • Microscopic agglutination test
  • ELISA
  • Indirect hemagglutination test
  • Macroscopic slide agglutination test

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition - Page no 284

questions.text: A 35 year old female patient was prescribed an unknown medicine for acute attack of migraine by some quack practitioner. After taking the drug she developed nausea and vomiting & tingling and numbness in the tip of the finger that also turned black as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely drug implicated in causing the above findings?
questions.solution:
Ergot Alkaloids

These are derived from a fungus called Claviceps purpurea. Important compounds are ergotamine, ergometrine (ergonovine), ergotoxine, bromocriptine, dihydroergotamine and methysergide. These drugs possess partial agonistic and antagonistic effect at 5HT, α and dopaminergic receptors.

These drugs are only α blockers that can cause vasoconstriction due to their partial agonistic activity on α and 5HT2 receptors (maximum with ergotamine). Hydrogenation of the compound decreases α agonistic activity but increases the α blocking potential. Therefore dihydroergotamine has very little vasoconstricting activity. Ergot derivatives can cause dry gangrene of the hands and feet as well as coronary vasospasm.

Ergotamine and dihydroergotamine are used for the treatment of acute attack of migraine. These are contraindicated in patients with ischemic heart disease (due to their propensity to cause coronary vasospasm).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p191

questions.text: Identify the bacteria in given image.
questions.solution:
Clostridium tetani is a common soil bacterium and the causative agent of tetanus Vegetative cells of clostridium tetani are usually rod shaped and upto 2.5 micron long. But they become enlarged and tennis racket shaped or drumstick appearance when forming spore.

When this bacterium enters the body they produce a toxin, which causes painful muscle contraction. Another name of this disease is Lock jaw.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition - Page no 252

questions.text: A sexually active male presents with a painful genital ulcer. The smear from the discharge is shown below. The causative organism is -
questions.solution:
Typical school of fish (Railroad track) appearance is characteristic of Haemophilus ducreyi.

It is a fastidious gram negative coccobacillus bacteria. It causes sexually transmitted disease chancroid, a major cause of genital ulceration in developing countries characterized by painful sores on the genitalia.

It doesn't cause urethritis. The remaining three organisms can cause urethritis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition - Page no 660
